articles.author: JB, FinOps Product Dept. Director & Core CS Team Lead
articles.description:
New!
  
We are happy to announce that new damage deposit payment settings are now available in your Smily account. Those new settings will allow you to better manage your damage deposit payments, as well as provide a better experience to your guests.
Why the changes?
Up until now, when going to your general damage deposit payment management settings (in Settings > Payments > Default preferences), the only option available regarding the collection of your damage deposit was the collection time: either with bookings payment or on arrival.
Both options led to the damage deposit being due via the Smily payment link, and to wrong information being displayed on the Smily payment page and the Smily booking contract in case you were managing your damage deposit via a partner app such as Swikly.
Wh…
articles.title: New damage deposit payment management setting

articles.author: Yannick, Customer Care Team Leader - Pro Team
articles.description:
Action required
  
Following our recent messages concerning the changes needed for your website domains, we would like to inform you that we have extended the support for the previous configuration until April 10 2023.
If you have not made the needeed changes yet, please consult our manual article here.
If you need assistance doing the changes, please contact our support team and we will be happy to assist you with the modifications. Please make sure to have access to your registrar (Gandi, OVH, Godaddy…) so we can assist you in performing this change.
Thanks,
articles.title: Reminder - Important information regarding your website domain!

articles.description:
Description: An issue in the Tailscale coordination server in device
reauthentication logic caused previously authenticated and tagged devices to
lose their ACL tags upon reauthentication.
What happened?
The logic that handles the reauthentication to a new identity on an
already-authenticated device with tags had a bug: instead of updating the
device’s logged-in identity to the newly authenticated user, the device’s
identity became that of the user who originally added it to the tailnet, without
any tags.
The bug was introduced on 2022-10-26, and discovered and remediated on
2023-04-21. The bug was discovered when troubleshooting a user-reported issue.
Who is affected?
189 tailnets triggered this bug in the course of normal use of Tailscale, either
directly by explicitly re-authenticating a device, or indirectly by using fast
user switching to switch between multiple
tailnets.
We have notified affected organizations where we have security
contacts.
What is the impact?
Devices that encountered the bug had their tags removed, which reverted the
device’s identity to that of the user who originally authenticated the device,
or the owner of the auth key that was originally used to authenticate the
device. In either case, this is the user listed as “Creator” in the Machines tab
of the admin panel. Depending on access rules in the tailnet policy file, this
could change the device’s network permissions.
We have analyzed the audit logs for affected tailnets, and found no evidence of
deliberate exploitation. In most instances, device owners noticed the incorrect
outcome of reauthentication, and corrected the device’s state themselves.
What do I need to do?
If you were not contacted by Tailscale, no action is required.  If you were
contacted by Tailscale, reapply the desired tags to affected devices in the
admin console, or by reauthenticating the devices. Tailscale has deployed a fix
to the coordination server as of 2023-04-21, and notified affected
organizations.
articles.title: TS-2023-005

articles.description:
Description: An issue in the Tailscale coordination server allowed tailnets created by GitHub organizations which were subsequently renamed to be associated with a new GitHub organization with the previous name.
What happened?
Tailscale mapped tailnets created by GitHub organizations to their organization name, rather than to their organization ID. This meant that if a GitHub organization was renamed, and the previous name taken over by a new GitHub organization, the existing tailnet would be tied to the new GitHub organization instead of the original one.
Who is affected?
Up to 1,305 tailnets created by GitHub organizations may have been affected, if those GitHub organizations were renamed between 2021-06-18 and 2023-03-30 and fully relinquished the old GitHub organization name. Additiona…
articles.title: TS-2023-004

Scheduled - As announced on July 5, 2021 we are deprecating our XML API connection.
XML listings can no longer be activated: this means that new XML listings will remain unlisted even if you set 
true
. The same is valid for existing listing that are deactivated (i.e. you will not be able to reactivate a XML listing if it gets unlisted).
More information about this enforcement here: https://developer.airbnb.com/docs/enforcement
articles.title: XML Migration Enforcement

articles.description:
Incident began at 2023-04-17 16:00 and ended at 2023-04-25 14:38 (times are in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC)).

Mini Incident Report

We apologize for the inconvenience this service disruption/outage may have caused. We would like to provide some information about this incident below. Please note, this information is based on our best knowledge at the time of posting and is subject to change as our investigation continues. If you have experienced impact outside of what is listed below, please reach out to Google Cloud Support using https://cloud.google.com/support or to Google Workspace Support using help article https://support.google.com/a/answer/1047213.

(All Times US/Pacific)

Incident Start: 17 April 2023 at 09:00

Incident End: 25 April 2023 at 07:38

Duration: 7 days, 22 hours, 38 minutes

Affected Services and Features:

Google Meet

Regions/Zones: Global

Description:

After an Operating System (OS) update, some Google Meet Hardware units were unable to boot into Meet reliably for a duration of 7 days, 22 hours and 38 minutes.

From preliminary analysis, the root cause of the issue was a latent issue that manifested due to specific network conditions on customer networks following an upgrade to the OS. Affected OS versions were those greater than 14816.84.1 but lower than 14816.84.35.

Google will complete a full IR in the following days that will provide a full root cause.

Customer Impact:

Impacted Google Meet hardware devices failed to launch the Meet app. Devices displayed a “Waiting for application window” message that never resolved, eventually went to sleep, and were shown as offline in the Google Admin Console. Some customers had to perform a manual reboot (occasionally several times), to overcome this issue.

Additional details:

Customers were provided with a temporary workaround with specific steps to overcome the issue. Google engineers also released a fix to the Beta channel on 21 April 2023 at 07:24 US/Pacific, while the workaround was being fully tested and rolled out to Stable fleet.

Affected products: Google Meet
articles.title: RESOLVED: We're investigating reports of an issue with Google Meet. We will provide more information shortly. The affected users are unable to access Google Meet, but we've provided a workaround below.

articles.description:
Issue Summary:

From April 19, 2023 at 3:05 PM PST until April 28, 2023 at 7:51 PM PST, customers signed in with an Enterprise Grid workspace may have experienced unexpected redirect behaviour when navigating https://slack.com/ links.


We appreciate your patience as we investigated the issue. Our engineering team has implemented a fix to resolve the routing behaviour; however, please reach out to feedback@slack.com if you continue to experience any trouble.
articles.title: Incident: Slack.com links are broken for some users on Enterprise Grid

articles.description:
Issue summary:

On April 24, 2023 from 11:25 AM PDT to 2:00 PM PDT, some users experienced issues with sending, shuffling and cancelling gifs using the Giphy app. We traced the issue to a recent update that impacted how we handle buttons in the /giphy slash command. 


We rolled back this change, resolving the issue for all impacted users.
articles.title: Incident: Users are not able to send, shuffle or cancel gifs with Giphy.

articles.description:
Issue Summary:

On April 20th, 2023 from 6:00 AM PDT until 7:45 AM PDT, a small number of users experienced latency issues when using Slack. Users reported a delay in loading threads, channels, direct messages, marking messages as read, and executing workflows. 


The issue resulted from an increased database load on one of our data center regions. We made a change in order manage the larger load and return to normal response times. 


Our team is continuing to look into what causes some queries to run slower than others to prevent degraded performance in the future.


Thank you for your patience while we worked through this. We apologize for any disruption to your work.
articles.title: Incident: A small percentage of users may be experiencing slowness in Slack.

articles.description:
Issue summary:


On April 16rd, 2023 from 12:11 PM PDT until 14:39 PM PDT, certain Android users on the Free plan reported issues with loading channels in the Android app.  


Upon investigation, this was attributed to the implementation of a data optimization feature, intended to improve app performance. We have rolled back this feature temporarily, which has corrected the observed issue.  A full investigation and remedy will take place prior to reimplementation. 


Thank you for your patience while we worked through this.  We apologize for any disruption to your work.
articles.title: Incident: Channels are missing for Android users

articles.description: This issue has now been resolved, please reload Slack to restore functionality to the direct messages view. Thank you for your patience while we worked on this.
articles.title: Incident: Direct messages view failing to load

articles.description:
Issue summary:

On April 10, 2023 at 7:30 PM PDT, some customers began experiencing delays when uploading files. We traced the issue back to a recent update made to how some file uploads are handled. Reverting this change fixed the issue, and customers were no longer experiencing it as of April 11, 2023 at 7:33 AM PDT. 


Thank you so much for your patience as our team actively worked on this.
articles.title: Incident: Images slow to upload

articles.description:
Issue summary: 

On April 3rd, 2023 from 11:00 AM PDT until 11:45 AM PDT, users on certain cellular service networks had issues receiving SMS texts for two-factor authentication (2FA). 


Upon investigation, this was traced to one unverified toll free number, which prevented 2FA codes from being approved for delivery. That number was removed from our 2FA pool, and services have resumed as usual. We are reviewing our process and alerting around outgoing phone number verification to ensure the issue doesn't happen again.
articles.title: Incident: Some users have trouble receiving 2FA code via SMS

articles.description:
Issue summary: 

From March 31st, 2023 at 7:18 PM PDT to April 1st, 2023 at 11:30 AM PDT, some customers may not have been able to sign in to Slack with the 'Continue with Google' feature. 


During a routine cleanup process, we made some changes to the project behind the 'Continue with Google' feature. This change inadvertently prevented the Slack mobile apps from confirming the validity of customer Google accounts during login. 


We reverted this change, restoring normal login behaviour for all affected customers, and we're working to ensure it does not happen again. We apologize for any disruption to your work.
articles.title: Incident: Some users are unable to sign-in using the Continue with Google feature on the Android and iOS app
